广告牌 https://www.billboard.com音乐排行榜、新闻、照片和视频2023 年 8 月 3 日星期四 20:15:05 +0000 en-US每小时1 https://wordpress.org/?v=6.2.2 Jaime Wyatt 谈在新歌“World Worth Keeping”中寻找自由https://www.billboard.com/music/country/jaime-wyatt-world-worth-keeping-outlaw-country-jail-1235384509/Dave Brooks Thu, 03 Aug 2023 20:14:57 +0000 CountryMusicInterivew https://www.billboard.com/?p=1235384509 The outlaw country artist talks love, lock-up and life as an artist, recording new music with Adrian Quesada of the Black Pumas.

她可能已经暂时搁置了她的白色牛仔帽，并将她标志性的两件式西服换成了粉色运动服，但杰米·怀亚特 (Jaime Wyatt) 仍然像以前一样是个亡命之徒。

37 岁的怀亚特 (Wyatt) 从来不是什么难事，她年轻时生活在华盛顿一个小镇上，过着老灵魂的生活，但在青少年时期却陷入了人生的低谷——沉迷于毒品、精神紧张、疯狂到想尝试。并抢劫毒贩。

怀亚特并不回避自己的过去，但也拒绝被 20 年前被关押在洛杉矶县监狱的自己所定义。如今，她是生活在边缘人群的直言不讳的声音，是生活在她准备抵制的州的 LGBT 活动家，也是准备挑战乡村音乐传统的不断发展的艺术家。她目前正在用新单曲“World Worth Keeping”来完成后者，这是一首根源和复兴赞歌，庆祝一个不完美的世界，以及那些让它值得保留的人。

这首歌曲由Black Pumas的 Adrian Quesada 制作，与 Wyatt 2020 年唱片《Neon Cross》中令人心碎的低级酒吧媚俗风格截然不同。她的新唱片《Feel Good》中的第一首单曲《World Worth Keeping》于 11 月 3 日在 New West Records 发行，感觉更像是一首 1960 年代的民权赞歌，具有永恒的抒情主题和易于聆听的情感，凸显了 Wyatts 的魅力。令人印象深刻的范围。

今年早些时候，怀亚特接受《公告牌》采访，谈论她的新音乐、她在监狱里的时光，以及一颗破碎的心苦乐参半的普世主义。以下是该对话的编辑版本。

我最近读了一篇关于你的简介，其中有一个有趣的小插曲，描述了一位粉丝在你的商品摊位上接近你，并测试你是否足够不法国家。你经常被人接近吗？

是的，国家有这种奇怪的东西，比如，“你是哪个国家的？你真的是乡下人吗？”答案是：“是的，我是。”当我还是个孩子的时候，我住在华盛顿的一辆拖车里。我们有马，我在马厩工作，我的父母听了很多乡村唱片。你还想从我这里得到什么？

既然您住在纳什维尔，您是否会受到更多质疑？

是的，当有些人发现我不是土生土长的田纳西人时，他们感到很惊讶。我有切罗基血统，我的家人从俄克拉荷马州搬到了加利福尼亚州，并在乐队中演奏以养活自己。事实证明，纳什维尔的大多数人都是非常了不起、可爱、富有同情心的人。但是，是的，有些人想测试我，我的反应是一样的——我没有时间。我真的只是想把时间花在创作音乐上。

作为乡村音乐领域的同性恋艺术家，您是否感到有压力需要更加积极地推动 LGBT 代表，或者您是否感到有压力不脱颖而出？

它每天都在变化。有时我走进一个场所，我会想，“我不想在这里成为同性恋。我今天不想成为同性恋。”我不会告诉他们我是谁，今天不会。其他日子，我会认真打牌。通常这是最好的。

您认为艺术家应该抵制推行反 LGBT 议程的国家吗？

是的，我住在田纳西州。但去他的吧，抵制他们。 F–king 很遗憾地说，但前几天我正在考虑这个问题，这就是引起人们注意的原因。不是我，而是像泰勒·斯威夫特这样的人。这就是需要的。

对你来说，路上的生活是什么样的？

现在我正在玩Head and the Heart。我正在演奏很多音乐节，并将其与乡村乐队和摇滚乐混合在一起。我喜欢这种类型的音乐探索。我们要和 My Morning Jacket 一起出去，我真的很喜欢他们的音乐并且受到他们的影响。巡演就是这样——在路上，每天晚上去别的地方。我们每天都在同一时间出现。这是我和我的音乐家们一生中最一致的经历。

告诉我你正在创作的新音乐。

我正在与 Black Pumas 的 Adrian Quesada 合作制作一张新唱片，我们在奥斯汀录制并制作了这张唱片。音乐是迄今为止我所做的最接近我的人生故事的事情。对我个人来说，这是关于坠入爱河，同时也移动并试图获得更多自由。

你是什​​么意思？

努力让自己感觉更好并照顾好自己的身体。试图减轻。这实际上更多的是关于音乐而不是歌词。就像，我制作的最后两张唱片很大程度上是歌手兼作曲家的曲目，锤炼着不同的隐喻，而这种方式更多的是我们制作这张唱片时我在脑海中听到的声音。

录制专辑的时候有没有恋爱过呢？

是的，但后来我又跌了回来。

这是一次重摔吗？

没有，但是很痛，就像摔得很厉害一样。

硬摔还是硬着陆？

老实说，着陆真是可悲。

你对它有多痛感到惊讶吗？

是的。

你想谈谈监狱吗？

是的，那容易多了。

只是在洛杉矶县监狱度过你的时光吗？

别误会我的意思，它也确实很混乱——但在某种程度上我喜欢它。没有来自社会的压力要求成为会计师，甚至支付账单。

这听起来有点过于理想化了。

是的，但任何与毒瘾作斗争的人都可以感受到它。监狱是一次他妈的旅行。

我听说你因抢劫毒贩而被捕？

嗯，是的，我想。我因抢劫毒贩而被捕，这并不罕见。我对海洛因上瘾；一切都太糟糕了。

你被关起来时几岁？

那年我20岁，在监狱里过了21岁。我最终做了八个月，然后又做了九个半月。

你是怎么熬过来的？

当我第一次到达那里时，我每天都很兴奋。你可以在任何地方使用，而我是个瘾君子——我一直都处于紧张状态。当我开始变得更好时，我会喜欢阅读和写不同角色的小故事。

这段经历改变了你吗？

我觉得我学到了很多关于社会的知识，说实话，这让我有点厌倦了。对社会为人们提供的东西感到厌倦。你出生的地方就像一张该死的彩票。这就是为什么大多数人都在那里——不是因为他们生来就是罪犯，而是因为他们生来就一无所有。

据你所知，你认为你会想要孩子吗？

这不是我要寻找的第一件事。我可能更希望有一个出色的电视广播员。或者是一只狗。别误会我的意思，孩子们都很酷。人类很酷。但我是个怪人。我必须走出去，体验世界并结识新朋友。我一直想与其他艺术家交流并录制音乐。在这种生活方式下——确实是我的生活方式——电视播音员似乎更实用。

; New Jeans 的“第二张 EP Get Up”和“Barbie”原声带如何进入年度第一专辑的最激烈竞争？ https://www.billboard.com/music/chart-beat/newjeans-2nd-ep-get-up-barbie-soundtrack- Five-burning-questions-1235384510/Andrew Unterberger Thu, 03 Aug 2023 20:06:46 +0000 Chart BeatMusicfive burning questions https://www.billboard.com/?p=1235384510 In this week's Five Burning Questions, we look at NewJeans' first No. 1 album on the Billboard 200, which edged the 'Barbie' soundtrack by a mere 500 units.

Billboard 200专辑榜年度第一名的最终结果于周三（8 月 2 日）公布，韩国流行五重奏NewJeans以 126,500 张的销量夺得第二张 EP《Get Up》的冠军宝座。首周（在 8 月 5 日的图表上）。

这仅比大片《芭比娃娃》的原声带多了 500 份，后者发行了 126,000 份，这是自 2019 年 Lady Gaga 和布莱德利·库珀的《一个明星的诞生》以来原声带单周销量最高的成绩。本周两人都位居前两名。也在Billboard Hot 100中占有一席之地：NewJeans 在 Hot 100 中占据了三首歌曲（其中先行单曲“Super Shy”排名第 48），而芭比原声带则占据了五首（由 Nicki Minaj 和 Ice Spice 的 Aqua 主演） 《芭比世界》排名第七）。

NewJeans 是如何以六首歌曲的 EP 首周表现如此出色的？为什么《芭比娃娃》原声带能如此迅速获得成功？ 《广告牌》工作人员将在下面讨论这些问题以及更多内容。

1. NewJeans 本周刚刚凭借他们的第二张 EP战胜了轰动一时的芭比原声带，首周销量达 126,500 张。您认为NewJeans如此迅速地登上Billboard排行榜的最大原因是什么？

Rania Aniftos ：他们太酷了。就那么简单。我（半）开玩笑，但我认为随着韩国流行音乐领域有如此多的男孩乐队突破全球主流，我们真的很渴望一些女孩的力量。 NewJeans 在吸引全球听众方面做得非常好，因为他们的歌曲不仅朗朗上口，而且还吸引了各个年龄段的粉丝。我见过孩子们随着《Super Shy》跳舞的 TikTok，他们和他们的父母一样喜欢它，这在音乐方面是非常独特的。

凯尔·丹尼斯：我认为 NewJeans 的到来恰逢其时。从几年前 BTS 和 BLACKPINK 在美国取得的突破，到最近 STRAY KIDS 和 TWICE 在 Billboard 200 上的胜利，美国市场目前对韩国流行音乐的接受度很高。从声音上来说，他们的新 EP 充满了主导美国主流的声音：英国车库和泽西俱乐部。再加上他们丰富的千禧年美学、流畅的旋律和不可抗拒的魅力，你将得到一张与 2023 年美国音乐和文化的现状非常契合的 EP，同时仍然感觉新鲜。

Lyndsey Havens ：我认为最大的原因是它的发布节奏——虽然 NewJeans 并没有压倒市场，但它的发布速度恰到好处，而且速度足够一致，以至于它们总是处于人们的首要考虑，而没有变得过度饱和。它的前两张 EP 发布时间大约相隔一年，其间充满了像“Ditto”、“OMG”和“Zero”这样的一次性作品——加上与 Jon Batiste 和 JID 的合作和混音，而且它们不仅与时机，但也包括质量，这可以说更为重要。

Jason Lipshutz ：NewJeans 的快速崛起——首先是《OMG》和《Ditto》等歌曲，现在又是这张排行榜冠军 EP——是由于他们结合了韩国流行音乐粉丝的吸引力和他们聪明、自然地偏离传统韩国音乐的特点。 -流行音乐制作。该乐队已经能够吸引大量听众，同时为他们提供新的东西，并在此过程中接触到非韩国流行乐迷：例如，“Super Shy”的视频包含了通常附属的团体编舞和个人个性展示。具有韩国流行音乐的视觉效果，但这首歌的节奏基础和拖曳的旋律同样可能迷惑 R&B 和超级流行乐迷。 NewJeans 提供了一种新的、广泛令人愉悦的流行音乐风格，并且它具有联系。

Andrew Unterberger ：NewJeans 显然处于 2023 年流行音乐的前沿——他们的声音可以用任何语言、任何观众播放——而且他们有歌曲创作、魅力和个性来支持制作。这是成功的秘诀——与许多同行不同，这一点已经在流媒体热门单曲和强劲的专辑销量中体现出来。

2. 尽管今年已经有几支 K-pop 乐队登上了 Billboard 200 排行榜的榜首，但 NewJeans 已经三度入围 Hot 100，从而从众多冉冉升起的新星中脱颖而出，其中以 Get Up 的《Super Shy》领衔，排名第 48 位本周已进入上市第三周。你认为它会成为更热门的流行歌曲吗？或者这是否是它可能出现的最好表现？

Rania Aniftos ：这可能只是一个开始。现在这张专辑已经荣登 Billboard 200 榜首，更多的潜在粉丝将被介绍到该乐队并欣赏他们的音乐。 《Super Shy》是一首如此有趣的歌曲，所以我无法想象 NewJeans 的粉丝不会继续推动它的成功。

凯尔·丹尼斯：我认为《Super Shy》绝对可以成为更热门的流行歌曲。显然，有了 TikTok，一切皆有可能，我们刚刚看到 FIFTY FIFTY 凭借《丘比特》在韩国流行广播电台上创造了历史。考虑到《Super Shy》在泽西俱乐部的影响力，这首歌与 PinkPantheress 和 Ice Spice 的《Boy's A Liar, Pt.》相比听起来并不会显得格格不入。 2”或 Bad Bunny 的“Where She Goes”，所以增长的潜力肯定是存在的。

Lyndsey Havens ：我认为两者兼而有之——这就是这一切的天才之处。配乐是如此完美地为这部电影量身定制，但它本身也很强大，因为杜阿·利帕 (Dua Lipa) 和比莉·艾利什 (Billie Eilish) 的原创歌曲在他们自己的项目中听起来就像在家里一样。 （真正的考验将是 Eilish 是否会在本周末 Lollapalooza 的头条演出中首次现场表演“What Was I Made For”）。另外，在发行日期提供物理格式可以让人们当场购买，并帮助原声带作为一个单独的、有形的实体存在。

Jason Lipshutz ：我不确定它会攀登多高，但“Super Shy”是今年最迷人的流行单曲之一 - 朗朗上口，活泼，带有空间感和亲密感。 FIFTY FIFTY 的《Cupid》最近的成功让我更加看好韩国流行单曲能够跨入美国排名前 40 的电台——这个平台通常对非体育场头条新闻不屑一顾——而且我认为《Super Shy》将在流行电台取得一些进展，以进入 Hot 100 的前 40 名。

Andrew Unterberger ：他们很快就会得到一个。 《Super Shy》似乎是官方跨界突破的一个不错的选择，但如果不是这首，一年后可能会是另一首。

3. 与此同时， 《芭比娃娃》发布了自 2019 年以来原声带的最佳单周销量。这主要是因为配套电影已经变得有多大，还是您认为原声带在完整聆听中建立了自己的角色？ ？

拉尼娅·阿尼夫托斯：两者都有！根据我的经验，我听原声带是因为我对芭比娃娃的幻想感到非常兴奋，但后来意识到那里有一些非常好的歌曲，它们在没有电影背景的情况下完美地独立存在。尽管芭比娃娃的炒作已经开始消退，但我发现自己仍在重复聆听原声带中的一些热门歌曲，而且我确信我不是唯一有这种感觉的人。

凯尔·丹尼斯：作为一个完整的套装，我对芭比的配乐并不着迷。尽管如此，专辑中还是有足够多的歌曲成为电影中令人难忘和关键的时刻，让原声带得以保留。显然，这部电影破纪录的成功帮助了这些首周的销量，但它有四首歌曲——《芭比世界》、《舞夜》、《极速驾驶》和《我是为了什么？》 - 成长为合法的流媒体和广播热门歌曲，我预计在未来几周内原声带的消费量将保持令人印象深刻的稳定性。

Lyndsey Havens ：我认为它会继续增长，特别是在 EP 首周令人印象深刻之后。虽然 NewJeans 已经探索了混音形式，但《Super Shy》似乎是一个理想的后续作品——我想现在愿意加入的艺术家名单已经很长了。

Jason Lipshutz ：前几天，我和妻子开车兜风，听 Spotify 上的“Today's Top Hits”播放列表，“Barbie World”与“Dance the Night”连续播放——对于一个大公司来说，这是一个非常好的迹象。预算配乐！芭比娃娃电影实际上已成为一种文化现象，它的成功显然促进了其随附专辑的首周销售，但原声带表现如此出色的主要原因是它有可以独立的热门歌曲。有些在芭比娃娃电影的背景下比其他的更重要，但是当你有大艺术家交付他们的顶级游戏并取得真正的排行榜成就时，你的配乐将会取得巨大的成绩。

Andrew Unterberger ：原声带非常有趣，从头到尾听起来相当连贯——不是每首歌都是瑰宝，但每首歌都保持着强劲的势头，而且有几首歌曲确实感觉像是真正的热门歌曲。作为一个还没有看过芭比娃娃电影的人（我知道，我知道，我很快就会看到它），如果我在聚会上或在乘车时有人放了配乐，我仍然会能够彻底地享受自己——这对于 2023 年的 OST 来说确实是罕见的。

4. 本周，芭比娃娃还有 6 首歌曲跻身热门 100 强：Nicki Minaj 和 Ice Spice 的 Aqua 主题歌曲“Barbie World”（第 8 名）、Dua Lipa 的“Dance the Night”（第 12 名）、Billie Eilish 的“What Was”我做的目的是什么？ （第 18 位）、Charli XCX 的“Speed Drive”（第 73 位）和 Ryan Gosling 的“I'm Just Ken”（第 87 位）。如果有的话，您认为当从更大的芭比娃娃环境中移除时，哪一个可以提供最佳的聆听效果？

Rania Aniftos ：我在“Dance the Night”和“What Was I Made For”之间左右为难。正如我们在“Levitating”中看到的那样，Dua 知道如何让迪斯科流行歌曲保持在排行榜、广播电台、俱乐部以及基本上任何可以听音乐的地方。 《舞夜》与我非常相似，所以我猜它也会产生类似的影响。与此同时，我已经看到“What Was I Made For”在 TikTok 上引起了听众的共鸣，因为新一代音乐听众似乎更加存在主义。他们将这些歌曲与自己的真实身份被利用或不被看见的经历联系起来，我认为这首歌会持续一段时间。

凯尔·丹尼斯：《芭比世界》是 Aqua 样本的有趣翻版，你会情不自禁地跟着一起跳，但对我来说，原声带的真正明星是比莉·艾利什的《我为何而生？》这绝对是一首毁灭性的民谣，在电影中占据了最好的位置，但是当脱离芭比娃娃的背景时，这首歌的歌词和制作也同样有效。当然，这对于夏天来说有点沉重，但你不能否认它的伟大。话又说回来，如果您真正挖掘了体内的 Kenergy，瑞恩·高斯林 (Ryan Gosling) 的“I'm Just Ken”总是值得聆听。

Lyndsey Havens ：就我个人而言，我一直无法停止听“I'm Just Ken”——实际上，这已经成为一个问题。但这首歌可以说是与电影最相关的……《芭比世界》也是如此。我认为这就是为什么“Dance the Night”和“Made For”对我影响最大的原因；这两部作品听起来都像是分别被留在了《Future Nostalgia》和《Happier Than Ever》的剪辑室地板上。但从电影的背景来看，它们听起来也像是专门为芭比娃娃制作的。这种二元性——同时与如此具体和如此普遍的事物产生共鸣——就是我认为这两首歌会继续攀升的原因。

Jason Lipshutz ：“舞夜之舞”，当然。也许芭比单曲不是 Dua Lipa 迄今为止最强的闪亮迪斯科流行单曲，但如果我们不渴望一首新的闪亮迪斯科流行单曲 Dua Lipa，我会被诅咒的，现在距离它已经过去了近三年半的时间。未来怀旧的发行。这首歌让我很着迷，在流行电台上听起来很棒，拥有今年所有热门单曲中最好的桥梁之一，并且每当芭比娃娃的炒作开始消散时，它都会继续表现良好。

Andrew Unterberger ：对我来说，《我是为了什么而生？》有多好，这几乎是滑稽的。是——比莉和芬尼斯本可以很容易地用他们的芭比之歌来打电话，但是这首歌却深入到了内心深处，听起来就像是一场特别情绪化的治疗课程。考虑到这首歌的商业性相对较低，以及仍有多少听众对它做出反应，你可以看出它的共鸣远远超出了芭比娃娃的诗句。

5. 今年并不总是排行榜上新流行血液最令人兴奋的一年，但 NewJeans 和Barbie热门歌曲的组合是我们最近经历过的最好的注入之一。目前计划（严格或宽松）于 2023 年发行的其他哪位流行歌手，您对今年的新专辑感到最兴奋？

拉尼娅·阿尼夫托斯：当然是奥利维亚·罗德里戈。她来拯救 2023 年流行音乐。相信我。

凯尔·丹尼斯：我对蕾妮·拉普（ 《雪天使》）和霍莉·亨伯斯通（ 《把我的卧室涂成黑色》）即将发行的唱片感到非常兴奋。

Lyndsey Havens ：嗯，我们已经从 Posty 那里得到了一张新专辑，所以即使我们在这里称呼它，现在我也会以高点结束这一年。也就是说，我最近听了很多赛琳娜·戈麦斯的歌，并对她的新专辑感到兴奋……当然，还有阿丽亚娜。也许随着《邪恶女巫》的制作暂停，她会冒险回到工作室……这些天，肯定有很多灵感来创作另一部（或几部）热门作品。

Jason Lipshutz ：“Rush”让我对 Troye Sivan 的新专辑充满期待，该专辑将于 10 月发行。他最终能跨界成为热门歌手吗？有多少歌曲能够达到主打单曲的极高品质？我很高兴看到 Sivan 的未来以及他能在商业上取得什么成就。

Andrew Unterberger ：Chappell Roan 的首张专辑还有很长的路要走，你只是希望它能得到应有的关注，成为今年最有趣、最搞笑的流行专辑之一。

在一段连续几周在社交媒体上占据主导地位的病毒视频中，格莱美奖得主、R&B 偶像亚瑟小子在他的My Way Las Vegas 驻场演出中照常营业。他在人群中发现了艾美奖获奖演员科科·帕尔默，为她唱了小夜曲，两人跳了一段简短但充满敬意的慢舞。他的手从未低于她的腰部，她的手也从未离开过他的肩膀。

然而，随着视频在社交媒体上传播，疯狂随之而来。从对女性产后自我表现的厌恶期望，到对现场表演礼仪细节的讨论，这段视频释放了潘多拉的话语魔盒。

有关的

《爸爸的家》：亚瑟小子重返拉斯维加斯驻地

2023年8月3日

数百万人不可避免地分享了他们的观点，但异性恋男性，尤其是年轻的异性恋男性对这种互动尤其强烈反对。曾经是美国文化结构的一个关键元素和一种常见的、没有争议的做法，现在已经成为引发不适、反对和彻底拒绝的风暴的中心。慢舞怎么了？对于年轻人来说，这种简单的成人仪式和共同经历是如何变得与上一代人完全不同的？

大多数 DJ 都认为，慢舞歌曲的主导声音一直是 R&B，尤其是深情的慢速歌曲，将浪漫和爱情作为当下的主要情感。但正如流媒体带来了超个性化的音乐消费和发现一样，慢舞方面的技术也是如此——至少 DJ Stylus（一位拥有 30 年职业 DJ 经验的人）是这么认为的。

“我进入 DJ 行业是因为这是一件神奇的事情，你以这种有趣的方式将音乐组合在一起，从而形成了特定时刻独有的独特共享体验，”他说。 “但我发现技术……破坏了公共体验。因此，对于那些甚至没有真正分享正在发生的事情的人来说，这几乎就像人们通过他们的设备享受这些表演时刻一样。我们都在一起，但我们都是孤独的。”

人们对 Z 世代及其与不断加快的技术进步的关系感到非常不安。还有一个事实是，由于 COVID-19 大流行和相关的封锁，Z 世代中的很大一部分人在其社会形成时期（高中结束和大学开始）度过了一些孤立和孤独的时光。这些年通常是举行毕业舞会和许多人第一次成人聚会等重要成人仪式的日子，但现在却从数百万年轻人手中夺走了。事实证明，慢舞是一种文化丰富的体验，很大程度上是因为这种练习如何将高度的亲密感和脆弱性融入核心记忆中——这种现象对于 Z 世代来说更难培养，因为科技在他们的生活中前所未有地无处不在。

“传统上，舞蹈是一种你知道自己可以在舞池上行走、音乐很美妙，然后你伸出手与某人跳舞的事情，”DJ Zoe Crazy 沉思道，她是 FAMU 2022 届毕业生，专门从事亚特兰大舞会 DJ。 “有了摄像头和社交媒体，它肯定会带走一些舒适感。你永远不知道你在和谁跳舞。你不知道谁在发布什么。一切都可以看到。我认为这会让人们变得更加挑剔。”

与之前的每一代人一样，Z 世代的生活充满了并置和矛盾。虽然这远不是​​他们的错，但尽管社交媒体将世界联系在一起，但它也以比以往任何时候都更直接、更广泛的影响力暴露了社会丑陋的一面。 Meme culture and reaction pictures and videos epitomize this; so many of those images are taken and circulated without the consent or knowledge of the subject, and no one wants to become the next meme on an Internet that remembers everything. Given that it has mostly grown up in the presence of phones, Gen Z is acutely aware of the dynamics at play when it comes to the convergence of social media and public spaces, and that hypervigilance undercuts the tenderness of the slow dance.

As with most things in life, the slow dance didn't just disappear on a random Tuesday. “It wasn't like it was an overnight drop off, but it's been a combination of things that have kind of led to it,” says DJ R-Tistic, one of the DJs that helped jumpstart the recent wave of slow dance discourse on Twitter. Classic slow dance songs still get played at the functions young people frequent, and young people are still getting on the dance floor, so all the necessary elements are present. Nonetheless, the dominance of the traditional slow dance has steadily waned. “I actually did an event for Pretty Little Thing the other day, and that's one of the younger crowds I've had in a minute,” says DJ R-Tistic. “There were a lot of 23–25-year-olds, and all they want to do is twerk.”

Just as the omnipresence of phones and cameras have stunted the ability to organically create moments of vulnerability to set the stage for a slow dance moment, so too has the evolution of the lyrical content of songs that sonically fit into the typical slow dance canon. “I feel like the content directly relates to it — to me, slow [dancing] goes with more romantic music,” DJ R-Tistic, who has been DJing for about 16 years, says. “Whether it's [Jodeci's] 'Forever My Lady,' a Luther [Vandross] song, or even, for the late '90s, a D'Angelo-Lauryn Hill 'Nothing Even Matters.' Those song are more about romance.” R-Tistic says around the turn of the century, he started to notice a transition: “I feel like the slow grind kind of started to take over … more sexual, slow-grinding type songs,” à la Ginuwine's “Pony and “So Anxious.”

Gen Z is less sexually conservative than every generation prior, and that attitude has extended to the dance floor. Twerking is king at most functions geared towards young people; conversely, young people's normalization of dance moves previously deemed as sexually explicit has left a hole in the experience they have gathered in the realm of slow dancing. “If you're in an era where you're sexually free and you've had therapy and you're shaking off the shackles of previous generations, all of a sudden, [slow dancing] is too intimate and scary?” questions DJ Stylus. “You don't mind if people's phones are on you, but a slow song with phones out is scary.”

In a way, as younger generations helped destigmatize twerking on the dance floor, there has been a related shift in the approach to slow dancing: Ironically, the once-chaste act of slow dancing may now be more taboo among young people, because of the intensity of its intimacy. When you are slow dancing, you are face to face with another person, staring into their eyes for an extended period of time. That is a stark difference from most approaches to twerking, where a woman's back is to another person's front, as a song that emphasizes the casualness of sexual interactions blasts in the background.

DJ Printz, a 13-year career DJ, connects dating app culture to the change in approach to slow dancing. “People are no longer beating around the bush, and we all know that we are sexual beings and overt sexuality is just something that we don't have to hide,” he says. “We're way more vulnerable when we're allowing somebody to share much more intimate moments. It's a harder thing to manage because technology has made it more difficult, and we don't practice those things as often.”

Gen Z's penchant for naming and changing unfair and unwelcoming cultural practices is well-documented. The traditionally binary-gendered exercise of slow dancing leaves out many people, especially for Gen Z, the most openly queer generation yet. While major cities like Los Angeles and New York are a bit more hospitable to open displays of queer slow dancing, that is not the case in many places around the word, especially with anti-LGBTQIA+ attitudes on the rise . Meanwhile, predatory men have made the dance floor feel unsafe and unwelcoming for women for decades due to harassment and groping, and Gen Z's dancing attitudes have shifted to start reflecting safety as the standard.

DJ Zoe Crazy notes that “You're very likely to see two women dancing” on the floor these days, partly due to the that prioritization of safety. “As far as two men dancing, it depends on the setting. At most venues you probably wouldn't find it, but at places where the LGBTQ community feels safe, it's very much likely.”

The evolution of slow dancing also goes hand in hand with the evolution of mainstream R&B. From Marvin Gaye to Mario , popular R&B had traditionally been an endlessly renewable resource of reliable slow songs. Most importantly, these were also love songs: Sure, some of them may have alluded to sex, but the focus was primarily on the wonder of romance.

In comparison, a sizable number of contemporary R&B songs are decidedly devoid of romance, despite their tempos and sonic motifs lending themselves well to the slow dance canon. While '90s R&B songs like Tevin Campbell's “Can We Talk” still enrapture younger audiences, albeit in the form of sing-a-longs as opposed to slow dancing, as both DJ Kosi and DJ Zoe Crazy note, some DJs have found it difficult to include many contemporary R&B hits in the slow jam section of the night. “They trend on social media, but then it's short lived,” says DJ Zoe Crazy. “I feel like if I play both [ Normani & Cardi B's ] 'Wild Side' or [ Muni Long's ] 'Hrs & Hrs,' it's like 'We're over that, let it go.'”

When it comes to today's biggest R&B stars — Summer Walker , Jhené Aiko , Ari Lennox , SZA , The Weeknd , etc. — pure romance often takes a backset to more heart-wrenching stories of betrayal and admissions and appraisals of toxic, emotionally immature behavior. Songs like Summer Walker and Jhené Aiko's “I'll Kill You” or SZA's “I Hate U,” aren't exactly the moments of lyrical sweetness that promote the doe-eyed vulnerability of a slow dance. Up-and-coming Gen Z DJ and music producer Kosi, agrees: “The lyrics and the content of the songs are important, and I don't think these songs are as essential or intimate in a positive way,” he says. “Right now, we don't have a lot of songs that feel right for slow dancing. The vibe is different.”

For DJ R-Tistic, the combination of contemporary hits with lackluster staying power and an influx of toxic lyricism has made incorporating contemporary R&B songs into the slow dance canon a bit of a challenge. The major exception he cites from the past decade is Ella Mai's “Boo'd Up,”: “It's slightly childish and sophomoric because of the lyrics, but it's still more on the romantic side.”

While the landscape of contemporary R&B certainly seems less hospitable to proper slow jams, that isn't to say that this generation is completely lacking in those kinds of ballads. “There's a canon of slow songs. Every generation has a canon, and every generation adds to the previous canon,” says DJ Stylus. “So, what is the modern slow dance song? I feel like it's Daniel Caesar's 'Best Part.'”

DJ R-Tistic agrees, saying that Daniel Caesar and HER's Grammy-winning duet is “one of the only songs from the last seven years that [he's] been requested to play at a wedding.” DJ Zoe Crazy also cites “Hrs & Hrs” as a similar new-age R&B slow dance song, in spite of its more sexually minded lyrics. (DJ Rose Gawd, who hosts artist-specific “R&B Nights,” even says that she's found some songs by Summer Walker and SZA can work as slow dance anthems — particularly the latter's “The Weekend.”)

To offset this imbalance of proper low-tempo romance-focused songs in contemporary R&B, some DJs have turned to Afrobeats. “I think it just it just works well, it's a global sound,” says DJ Zoe Crazy. DJ R-Tistic notes that some Afrobeats songs have begun to serve the purpose of your typical R&B slow dance song. “'Essence' [ Wizkid & Tems ] is technically pretty fast, it's 104 BPM, but it still kind of serves that two-step face-to-face type deal,” he says.

While a two-step is still a bit removed from a proper slow dance, it is still closer to the practice than the barrage of TikTok dances and nondescript bopping motions most often inspired by contemporary hip-hop hits. DJ Printz loves Afrobeats because the genre “replaced the lack of energy from hip-hop when it comes to these danceable songs, on top of the fact that the energy they bring with the content of the song is also upbeat… it's loving, like an R&B song, but it's not necessarily an R&B song.”

While there are obviously Afrobeats songs that are just as sexual as contemporary R&B and hip-hop, the genre seems houses more current songs that are simply about love and romance — and DJs are turning to those tracks to fill those voids in their sets, while still accounting for contemporary music trends. DJ Stylus likens Afrobeats' current dominance to that of dancehall in the mid-late '90s and early aughts; “It's like this lingua franca of moving your ass that connects us across the diaspora from New Orleans to Accra.”

The seismic changes in technological innovation and musical evolution converge in streaming, which has, in many ways, upended our previous collective understanding of the cultural zeitgeist. As a result, younger Gen Z audiences, as well as Gen Alpha, now must grapple with reconciling infinite choice based on their personal taste with a setting where a DJ is in (almost) complete control of the experience.

“Because everything is so hyper-individual on command, what happens is people come into what is supposed to be a social and communal space trying to impose individual demands with no regard for context or anyone else,” argues DJ Stylus. If you are going to a function with the expectation that the DJ will play all your specific favorite records, the battle for the slow dance, or dancing at all, has already been lost. With fewer contemporary R&B hits reaching and remaining in the cultural zeitgeist, Gen Z's relationship to slow dancing gets even more precarious. “I think we're really selfish,” DJ Kosi says. “People go to parties to only hear songs that they want to hear.”

However, the hyper-individual nature of contemporary culture has also allowed those seeking slow dance moments to find events and DJs tailor-made for those feelings. DJ Rose Gawd notes, “There's room for everybody. And there's also a need for those people who do just know how to keep things simple or who do know how to slow it down.”

DJ Rose Gawd's artist nights have proven to be rousing successes, dating back to her first Aaliyah -centric event back when the pandemic's peak had first started to wane. Events centered on a specific genre or artist have become increasingly commonplace in recent years, a simultaneous symptom of the surplus of choice induced by streaming and an acknowledgement of the fact that people of all ages are still craving experiences that may no longer be the cultural norm.

“I did have some students come up asking for slow jams so they could dance with their significant other, which might be surprising to some,” says DJ Zoe Crazy about this spring's Atlanta prom season. “There's definitely some young teens that, when they go to prom, want to have those moments.”

In that word — “moments” — lies the root of slow dancing's curious evolution. Gen Z lives in a world and culture predicated on the idea of moments and capturing them, coupled with the increased aestheticization of life in the TikTok era. In this world, moments are meant to be captured, not experienced, or lived in. Thus, the slow dance has become tied to specific events to fulfill the “moment” each event should look like, whether that be a wedding or a prom. Slow dancing is no longer something that is expected to happen at any random party, because then it no longer becomes a moment that completes a specific aesthetic. Now, because slow dancing has become increasingly tied to stable partnerships and major events, when it does happen between two strangers at a standard concert — even strangers as famous as Usher and Keke Palmer — the concept reads as foreign.

Of course, a good DJ can still swing some level of slow dancing out of a crowd, but changing attitudes and behaviors have made that part of their job quite different than it has been in the past. Slow dancing hasn't died, it's just going through a phase — one that leads longtime DJs to wonder how exactly the culture will continue to shift in the era of Gen Z.

“Cultural norms and cultural signposts do evolve and change,” says DJ Stylus. “But what does that mean when it comes to certain types of music and how it creates human connection and human experiences?”

The remix, released July 21 through Ztekk/Simple Stupid/Geffen/Interscope Records, opens with 7.6 million radio airplay audience impressions (up 26%), 4.2 million US streams (up 136%) and less than 1,000 downloads sold (up 187%) in the July 21-27 tracking week, according to Luminate.

Messia's original solo version, released Jan. 20, has been climbing Billboard ’s charts since early July. This week, it rises 16-15 on Rap Airplay, 29-26 on Mainstream R&B/Hip-Hop Airplay, 33-31 on Rhythmic Airplay and 36-32 on R&B/Hip-Hop Airplay.

(All versions of the song are combined for one singular listing on Billboard ’s charts.)

Messia, who was born in Jamaica and is based in Saint Kitts and Nevis, is a newcomer to Billboard ’s charts. “Talibans” is his first song to chart. In June, he scored his first overall chart appearance , when his collection No Love , featuring the track, debuted at No. 8 on Reggae Albums. The set hits a new No. 3 high on the latest list.

Before No Love , Messia released six albums: Different Perspectives (in 2017), Top 10 (2017) (2017), Byron Messia (Top 2018) (2020), SIGH (2020), HitsTapes (2020) and Pills Nd Pain (2021).

Meanwhile, Burna Boy, from Nigeria, expands his Billboard chart history with “Talibans II.” It marks his third appearance on the Hot 100, after his featured turn on Justin Bieber's “Loved By You” in 2021 (No. 87 peak) and “Last Last” in October (No. 44 peak). He also boasts 30 entries on the Billboard US Afrobeats Songs chart since the survey originated last year, the second-most after Asake (32). “Last Last” spent eight weeks at No. 1 on that chart, the second-longest reign after Rema and Selena Gomez's “Calm Down” (48 weeks).

One of Taylor Swift 's The Eras Tour crew members is speaking out about how much her generosity helps those she employs.

News broke earlier this week that the “Bejeweled” superstar gave $100,000 bonuses to each truck driver of her tour before the Saturday night (July 29) show in Santa Clara, Calif., according to TMZ and ET . Swift has around 50 drivers on her tour, making the total amount of money around $5 million.

Mike Scherkenbach, who runs concert transportation company Shomotion and has worked on a number of Swift's tours over the years, told Rolling Stone on Thursday (Aug. 3) that Swift has always been generous, but the latest bonuses have been “life-changing” to the drivers.

“She's giving a sum of money that is life-changing for these people,” he told the publication. “A lot of these drivers are not homeowners, and a lump sum like this gives you the ability to put a down payment on a home. That's what makes me really happy. That generosity is a game changer for these people.”

She also reportedly gave bonuses to band members, dancers, lighting and sound technicians, caterers and other crew members. Scherkenbach said most artists of Swift's level of fame typically give drivers $5,000 to $10,000 extra, making Swift particularly generous.

“They did the documentary on the last tour, Reputation , for Netflix, and she listed my drivers in the credits,” he added of Swift and her team. “To put the drivers' names in the movie credits? That shows the character of a person.”

He continued, “The comments that I read that bother me the most are when they're comparing [what she gives] to her net worth. That's irrelevant. There are a lot of very wealthy people who choose not to share a dime of it. We work with all kinds of wealthy people, but this is not the norm.”

The Eras Tour's US leg concludes with six shows at Los Angeles' SoFi Stadium (Aug. 3-5 and 7-9).

; Peter Gabriel Takes the 'Road' Back to Billboard's Airplay Charts https://www.billboard.com/pro/peter-gabriel-road-to-joy-adult-alternative-airplay-debut/Kevin Rutherford Thu, 03 Aug 2023 18:59:38 +0000 Chart BeatMusicMusic Newsrock https://www.billboard.com/?post_type=billboard_pro_post&p=1235384479 He makes his first visit to a radio ranking as a lead artist since 2002.

Peter Gabriel is back on a Billboard airplay chart for the first time since 2008 — and for the first time as a lead artist since 2002 — with “Road to Joy,” which debuts at No. 37 on the Adult Alternative Airplay tally dated Aug. 5.

The song marks Gabriel's first entry on an airplay ranking since he was featured on Big Blue Ball 's “Burn You Up, Burn You Down,” which peaked at No. 18 on Adult Alternative Airplay in 2008. ( Big Blue Ball is also the name of the 2008 album recorded by Gabriel and a variety of artists, including Joseph Arthur and Sinead O'Connor , with Gabriel supplying vocals on multiple songs.)

Between 2002 and 2008, Gabriel also hit Adult Alternative Airplay as a featured vocalist on Angelique Kidjo 's “Salala,” which reached No. 27 in 2007.

His last time as a lead artist on Adult Alternative Airplay (which began in 1996) prior to “Road to Joy” had been in 2002, when “More Than This” peaked at No. 20.

Gabriel boasts four No. 1s as a solo artist on Billboard ’s Mainstream Rock Airplay chart, earned in the 1980s and '90s (“Shock the Monkey,” “Sledgehammer,” “In Your Eyes” and “Digging in the Dirt”); two on Alternative Airplay in the '90s (“Digging in the Dirt” and “Steam”); and one on Adult Alternative Airplay in the 2000s (as featured on Afro Celt Sound System 's “When You're Falling”).

The former lead singer of Genesis first hit Billboard ’s charts on his own in 1977. Among his five solo top 40 hits on the multimetric, all-genre Billboard Hot 100 , “Sledgehammer” ruled for a week in 1986. He has tallied three top 10s on the Billboard 200 albums chart, one each in the '80s ( So , No. 2), '90s ( Us , No. 2) and '00s ( Up , No. 9).

“Road to Joy” is one of multiple tastes of I/O , Gabriel's upcoming 10th studio album. A specific release date has not been announced, but Gabriel has released a new song from the LP during every full moon each month, with the 12th set for December. It's his first album of original material since Up in 2002.
